item.title: Many-body localization and particle multioccupancy in the disordered Bose-Hubbard model
item.description:
Author(s): Jie Chen, Chun Chen, and Xiaoqun Wang

We study the potential influence of the particle multi-occupations on the stability of many-body localization in the disordered Bose-Hubbard model. Within the higher-energy section of the dynamical phase diagram, we find that there is no apparent finite-size boundary drift between the thermal phase …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 134205] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Jie Chen, Chun Chen, and Xiaoqun Wang

We study the potential influence of the particle multi-occupations on the stability of many-body localization in the disordered Bose-Hubbard model. Within the higher-energy section of the dynamical phase diagram, we find that there is no apparent finite-size boundary drift between the thermal phase …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 134205] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Possible frustrated superconductivity in kagome superconductors
item.description:
Author(s): Hong-Min Jiang, Wen-Qian Dong, Shun-Li Yu, and Z. D. Wang

Geometric frustration has long been a subject of enduring interest in condensed matter physics. While geometric frustration traditionally focuses on magnetic systems, little attention is paid to the “frustrated superconductivity” which could arise when the superconducting interaction conflicts with …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 134512] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Enhanced superconductivity in bilayer kagome borophene by alkali and alkaline earth metal deposition
item.description:
Author(s): Ying-Jie Chen, Meng-Meng Zheng, Ping Zhang, and Hong-Yan Lu

The successful synthesis of bilayer borophene has stimulated interest in further research on boron-based materials. Recently, Gao $et \mathit{al}$. predicted a new bilayer kagome borophene (BK-borophene) with multiple van Hove singularities [Adv. Sci. 11, 2305059 (2024)]. The peculiar influence of v…

item.title: Intrinsic nonlinear valley Nernst effect in the strained bilayer graphene
item.description:
Author(s): Ying-Li Wu, Jia-Liang Wan, and Xiao-Qin Yu

We theoretically analyze the nonlinear valley Nernst effect (NVNE) as the second-order response of temperature gradient through the semiclassical framework of electron dynamics. Our study shows that an intrinsic nonlinear pure valley current can be generated vertically to the applied temperature in …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 144104] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Mott transition and correlation effects on strictly localized states in an octagonal quasicrystal
item.description:
Author(s): Efe Yelesti, Onur Erten, and M. Ö. Oktel

Flat-band systems have attracted significant attention as platforms for studying strongly correlated electron physics, where the dominance of electron-electron interactions over kinetic energy gives rise to a variety of emergent phenomena. Quasicrystals are compelling systems for studying these phen…

item.title: Identification of intrinsic and extrinsic in-plane twofold symmetry in ${\mathrm{CsV}}_{3}{\mathrm{Sb}}_{5}$ via transport measurements
item.description:
Author(s): Yu-Chi Yao, Fei Sun, Andrea Capa Salinas, Stephen D. Wilson, Phil D. C. King, and Haijing Zhang

Resolving in-plane twofold symmetry in layered superconductors is challenging, as extrinsic effects can easily mimic intrinsic signals. The authors focus here on the kagome superconductor CsV3Sb5, and systematically explore how current direction, magnetic field alignment, and structural domains influence transport measurements. Their study establishes a refined framework to distinguish genuine electronic symmetry breaking from experimental artifacts.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 144511] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Yu-Chi Yao, Fei Sun, Andrea Capa Salinas, Stephen D. Wilson, Phil D. C. King, and Haijing Zhang

Resolving in-plane twofold symmetry in layered superconductors is challenging, as extrinsic effects can easily mimic intrinsic signals. The authors focus here on the kagome superconductor CsV3Sb5, and systematically explore how current direction, magnetic field alignment, and structural domains influence transport measurements. Their study establishes a refined framework to distinguish genuine electronic symmetry breaking from experimental artifacts.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 144511] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025
item.dc:title: Identification of intrinsic and extrinsic in-plane twofold symmetry in ${\mathrm{CsV}}_{3}{\mathrm{Sb}}_{5}$ via transport measurements

We investigate the structural and electronic properties of such strain-induced moiré patterns in TMD homobilayers. These moiré patterns consist of several stacking domains separated by ten…

item.title: Universal quasi-Fermi liquid physics of one-dimensional interacting fermions
item.description:
Author(s): Joshua D. Baktay, Adrian E. Feiguin, and Julián Rincón

We present a class of one-dimensional, generic, spinless fermion lattice Hamiltonians that express quasi-Fermi liquid physics, manifesting both Luttinger and Fermi liquid features solely due to irrelevant interactions. Using infinite matrix product state techniques, we unveil its universal structure…


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L161116] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.description:

item.title: Interplay between electronic and atomic short-range order in ${\mathrm{La}}_{2−x}{\mathrm{Ca}}_{x}{\mathrm{CuO}}_{4−δ}$: Temperature and doping dependence
item.description:
Author(s): S. Hameed, Y. Liu, K. S. Rabinovich, G. Kim, M. Neumann, P. Wochner, G. Christiani, G. Logvenov, K. Higuchi, N. B. Brookes, E. Weschke, F. Yakhou-Harris, A. V. Boris, B. Keimer, and M. Minola

Complex oxides are well-known to develop oxygen ordering patterns with well-defined periodicities, but their interplay with the electronic structure remains largely unexplored. Here, we report resonant and nonresonant x-ray diffraction data indicating a four-unit-cell periodic superstructure related…


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L161114] Published Fri Oct 10, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): S. Hameed, Y. Liu, K. S. Rabinovich, G. Kim, M. Neumann, P. Wochner, G. Christiani, G. Logvenov, K. Higuchi, N. B. Brookes, E. Weschke, F. Yakhou-Harris, A. V. Boris, B. Keimer, and M. Minola

Complex oxides are well-known to develop oxygen ordering patterns with well-defined periodicities, but their interplay with the electronic structure remains largely unexplored. Here, we report resonant and nonresonant x-ray diffraction data indicating a four-unit-cell periodic superstructure related…


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L161114] Published Fri Oct 10, 2025

item.title: Partial suppression of magnetism in the square lattice SU(3) Hubbard model
item.description:
Author(s): Samuel Bird, Sebastian Huber, and Jannes Nys

The $\mathrm{SU}(N)$ Hubbard model is a natural extension of the $\mathrm{SU}(2)$ model. However, even the $N=3$ case remains poorly understood. We report a ground-state phase diagram of the square lattice $\mathrm{SU}(3)$ Fermi-Hubbard model. Using a backflow Ansatz, we identify strong signatures o…

item.title: Highly anisotropic surface resonance states in the kagome semimetal ${\mathrm{Ni}}_{3}{\mathrm{In}}_{2}{\mathrm{Se}}_{2}$
item.description:
Author(s): Kaiyi Zhai, Xian Du, Cheng Chen, Wujun Shi, Wenxuan Zhao, Yidian Li, Zhongkai Liu, Yangyang Lv, Yulin Chen, and Lexian Yang

Shandite kagome materials offer a versatile platform for investigating intriguing quantum phenomena, due to their rich tunability and the synergy of magnetism, topology, and electronic correlations. Here, the authors directly observe surface resonance states on the shandite kagome crystal Ni3In2Se2 using high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES). These surface states exhibit massive Dirac-like dispersions with highly anisotropic effective masse, an unusual feature in three-dimensional materials. Surface-confined states with relatively large spin–orbit coupling effects is potentially useful in surface science.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 155124] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Kaiyi Zhai, Xian Du, Cheng Chen, Wujun Shi, Wenxuan Zhao, Yidian Li, Zhongkai Liu, Yangyang Lv, Yulin Chen, and Lexian Yang

Shandite kagome materials offer a versatile platform for investigating intriguing quantum phenomena, due to their rich tunability and the synergy of magnetism, topology, and electronic correlations. Here, the authors directly observe surface resonance states on the shandite kagome crystal Ni3In2Se2 using high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES). These surface states exhibit massive Dirac-like dispersions with highly anisotropic effective masse, an unusual feature in three-dimensional materials. Surface-confined states with relatively large spin–orbit coupling effects is potentially useful in surface science.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 155124] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025

item.title: Aubry pinning transition of twisted two-dimensional material bilayers
item.description:
Author(s): Jin Wang and Erio Tosatti

Bilayers of 2D materials such as graphene are frictionally pinned at perfect alignment but free sliding (“superlubric”) at large twists. Small-twist bilayers, heavily reconstructed, might equally remain superlubric, or turn spontaneously pinned through a so-called Aubry transition. Here, simulation and theory show that small twist graphene and other 2D bilayers remain unpinned even under high loads. A geometric criterion useful for future microscale friction planning–-the width of moiré domain walls larger than four lattice spacings-–characterizes this robust superlubricity.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 155406] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Jin Wang and Erio Tosatti

Bilayers of 2D materials such as graphene are frictionally pinned at perfect alignment but free sliding (“superlubric”) at large twists. Small-twist bilayers, heavily reconstructed, might equally remain superlubric, or turn spontaneously pinned through a so-called Aubry transition. Here, simulation and theory show that small twist graphene and other 2D bilayers remain unpinned even under high loads. A geometric criterion useful for future microscale friction planning–-the width of moiré domain walls larger than four lattice spacings-–characterizes this robust superlubricity.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 155406] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025
item.dc:title: Aubry pinning transition of twisted two-dimensional material bilayers

item.title: Probing quasiparticle excitations in a doped Mott insulator via Friedel oscillations
item.description:
Author(s): Anurag Banerjee, Emile Pangburn, Catherine Pépin, and Cristina Bena

In this work, we investigate impurity-induced Friedel oscillations in the doped two-dimensional Hubbard model, focusing on the role of holon and doublon excitations. We show that weak impurities, due to the nonfermionic nature of the underlying quasiparticles, induce Friedel oscillations whose behav…
